translated: who are favored by the Lord, who are desirous of liberation. That knowledge of theirs is the agent. Like the sun,

original: yathādityaḥ svodayamātreṇaiva tamo niravaśeṣaṃ nivartayati na tu kaṃcit sahāyam
analyzed: yathā ādityaḥ sva udaya mātreṇa eva tamaḥ niravaśeṣam nivartayati na tu kaṃcid sahāyam
translated: just as the sun removes darkness completely merely by its own rising, and does not depend on anything else,

original: apekṣate tathā brahmajñānam api śuddhasattvapariṇāmatvād vyāpakaprakāśarūpaṃ🔽svotpattimātreṇaiva sahakāryantaranirapekṣatayā sakāryam ajñānaṃ nivartayat param
analyzed: apekṣate tathā brahma jñānam api śuddha sattva pariṇāma tvāt vyāpaka prakāśa rūpam  sva utpatti mātreṇa eva sahakāri antara nirapekṣa tayā sa kāryam ajñānam nivartayat param
translated: so also the knowledge of Brahman, being the transformation of pure sattva, is of the nature of all-pervading light,

original: satyajñānaānantānandarūpam ekam evādvitīyaṃ paramātmatattvaṃ prakāśayati praticchāyāgrahaṇamātreṇaiva
analyzed: satya jñāna a ananta ānanda rūpam ekam eva advitīyam paramātma tattvam prakāśayati prati chāyā grahaṇa mātreṇa eva
translated: and merely by its own origination, independently of any other cooperating factor, removes ignorance along with its effects, and reveals the supreme reality of Brahman, which is of the nature of truth, knowledge, infinity, bliss, one without a second,

original: karmatām antareṇābhivyanakti /
analyzed: karmatām antareṇa abhivyanakti
translated: by merely grasping its reflection, it manifests its state of being an object without any action.

original: atrājñānenāvṛtaṃ jñānena nāśitam ity ajñānansyāvaraṇatvajñānanāśyatvābhyāṃ jñānābhāvarūpatvaṃ vyāvartitam /
analyzed: atra ajñānena āvṛtam jñānena nāśitam iti jñāna abhāva rūpa tvam vyāvartitam
translated: Here, the form of non-knowledge as the absence of knowledge is excluded by non-knowledge being a covering and being destroyed by knowledge, as stated in covered by non-knowledge, destroyed by knowledge.

original: nahy abhāvaḥ kiṃcid āvṛṇoti na vā jñānābhāvo jñānena nāśyate svabhāvato nāśarūpatvāt tasya /
analyzed: nahi abhāvaḥ kiṃcid āvṛṇoti na vā jñāna abhāvaḥ jñānena nāśyate svabhāvataḥ nāśa rūpa tvāt tasya
translated: For an absence does not cover anything, nor is the absence of knowledge destroyed by knowledge, because it has the nature of destruction by itself.

original: tasmād aham ajño mām anyaṃ ca na jānāmīty ādisākṣipratyakṣasiddhaṃ bhāvarūpam evājñānam iti bhagavato matam /
analyzed: tasmāt aham ajñaḥ mām anyam ca na jānāmi iti ādi sākṣi pratyakṣa siddham bhāva rūpam eva ajñānam iti bhagavataḥ matam
translated: Therefore, the Blessed Lord's opinion is that ignorance is indeed an existent, directly perceived by the witness, as established by such direct perceptions as I am ignorant, I do not know myself or others, and so on.

original: vistaras tv advaitasiddhau draṣṭavyaḥ /
analyzed: vistaraḥ tu advaitasiddhau draṣṭavyaḥ
translated: But the details should be seen in the Advaita Siddhi.

original: yeṣām iti bahuvacanenāniyamo darśitaḥ /
analyzed: yeṣām iti bahuvacanena aniyamaḥ darśitaḥ
translated: And by the plural in of them, irregularity is shown.

original: tathā ca śrutiḥ tad yo yo devānāṃ pratyabudhyata sa eva tad abhavat tatha rṣīṇāṃ
analyzed: tathā ca śrutiḥ tat yaḥ yaḥ devānām pratyabudhyata saḥ eva tat abhavat rṣīṇām
translated: And so the Śruti: He who understood it among the gods, he alone became that. So also among the sages,

original: tathā manuṣyāṇāṃ tad idam apy etarhi ya evaṃ vedāhaṃ brahmāsmīti sa idaṃ sarvaṃ bhavati
analyzed: tathā manuṣyāṇām tat idam api etarhi yaḥ evam veda aham brahma asmi iti saḥ idam sarvam bhavati
translated: and among men. Even now, he who knows thus, 'I am Brahman,' he becomes all this.

original: ity ādir yad viṣayaṃ yadāśrayam ajñānaṃ tadviṣayatadāśrayapramāṇajñānāt tannivṛttir
analyzed: iti ādiḥ yad viṣayam yad āśrayam ajñānam tad viṣaya tad āśraya pramāṇa jñānāt tad nivṛttiḥ
translated: Thus, the cessation of ignorance is by the knowledge of the means of valid knowledge, which has that as its object and that as its basis.🔽This is the established conclusion.

original: iti nyāyaprāptam aniyamaṃ darśayati /
analyzed: iti nyāya prāptam aniyamam darśayati
translated: And he shows the irregularity thus obtained.

original: tatrājñānagatam āvaraṇaṃ dvividham ekaṃ sato 'py asattvāpādakam anyat tu bhāto 'py abhānāpādakam /
analyzed: tatra ajñāna gatam āvaraṇam dvividham ekam sataḥ pi asattva āpādakam anyat tu bhātaḥ pi abhāna āpādakam
translated: There, the obscuration that pertains to ignorance is of two kinds: one that causes non-existence even of what exists, and the other that causes non-appearance even of what appears.

original: tatrādyaṃ parokṣāparokṣasādhāraṇapramāṇajñānamātrān nivartate /
analyzed: tatra ādyam parokṣa aparokṣa sādhāraṇa pramāṇa jñāna mātrāt nivartate
translated: Among them, the first is removed by the mere knowledge of a means of valid knowledge that is common to both the hidden and the manifest.

original: anumite 'pi vahnyādau parvate vahnir nāstīty ādibhramādarśanāt /
analyzed: anumite vahni ādau parvate vahniḥ na asti iti ādi bhrama adarśanāt
translated: Because even in an inference like there is fire on the mountain, the illusion that there is no fire is not seen.

original: tathā satyaṃ jñānam anantaṃ brahmāsti iti vākyāt parokṣaniścaye 'pi brahma nāstīti bhramo nivartata eva /
analyzed: tathā satyam jñānam anantam brahma asti iti vākyāt parokṣa niścaye brahma na asti iti bhramaḥ nivartate eva
translated: Similarly, even when there is a hidden certainty from the statement Brahman exists, is truth, knowledge, and infinite, the illusion that Brahman does not exist is removed.

original: asty eva brahma kintu mama na bhātīty ekaṃ bhramajanakaṃ dvitīyam abhānāvaraṇaṃ
analyzed: asti eva brahma kintu mama na bhāti iti ekam bhrama janakam dvitīyam abhā anāvaraṇam
translated: One illusion-producing [statement] is Brahman exists, but it does not appear to me. The second, the obscuration of non-appearance,

original: sākṣātkārād eva nivartate /
analyzed: sākṣātkārāt eva nivartate
translated: is removed only by direct perception.

original: sa ca sākṣātkāro vedāntavākyenaiva janyate nirvikalpaka ity ādy advaitasiddhāv anusandheyam ////
analyzed: sa ca sākṣātkāraḥ vedānta vākyena eva janyate nirvikalpakaḥ iti ādi advaitasiddhau anusandheyam
translated: And that direct perception is produced only by the Vedanta statement, and is non-conceptual. This should be understood in the proof of non-dualism.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha.

original: yathāvidyā tasya jñānam āvṛṇoti /
analyzed: yathā vidyā tasya jñānam āvṛṇoti
translated: As ignorance covers that knowledge,

original: tathaivāparā tasya vidyāśaktir avidyāṃ vināśya jñānaṃ prakāśayatīty arthaḥ /
analyzed: tathā eva aparā tasya vidyā śaktiḥ avidyām vināśya jñānam prakāśayati iti arthaḥ
translated: in the same way, another power of knowledge of that, destroying ignorance, illuminates knowledge - this is the meaning.

original: jñānena vidyāśaktyā /
analyzed: jñānena vidyā śaktyā
translated: By knowledge, by the power of knowledge.

original: ajñānam avidyām /
analyzed: ajñānam avidyām
translated: Ignorance, ignorance.

original: teṣāṃ jīvānāṃ jñānam eva kartṛ ādityavad ityādityaprabhā yathāndhakāraṃ vināśya ghaṭapaṭādikaṃ prakāśayati /
analyzed: teṣām jīvānām jñānam eva kartṛ āditya vat iti āditya prabhā yathā andhakāram vināśya ghaṭa paṭa ādikam prakāśayati
translated: The knowledge of those souls is the agent, like the sun. Just as the sun's rays destroy darkness and illuminate pots, clothes, etc.,

original: tathaiva vidyayaivāvidyāṃ vināśya tajjīvaniṣṭhaṃ jñānaṃ param aprākṛtaṃ prakāśayati /
analyzed: tathā eva vidyayā eva avidyām vināśya tat jīva niṣṭham jñānam param aprākṛtam prakāśayati
translated: in the same way, by knowledge alone, having destroyed ignorance, it illuminates that supreme, unmanifest knowledge residing in the soul.

original: tena parameśvaro na kam api badhnāti /
analyzed: tena parameśvaraḥ na kam api badhnāti
translated: Therefore, the Supreme Lord does not bind anyone,

original: nāpi kam api mocayati /
analyzed: na api kam api mocayati
translated: nor does He liberate anyone.

original: kintv ajñānajñāne prakṛter eva dharmaḥ krameṇa badhnāti mocayati ca /
analyzed: kintu ajñāna jñāne prakṛteḥ eva dharmaḥ krameṇa badhnāti mocayati ca
translated: But ignorance and knowledge are the qualities of Prakṛti itself, which bind and liberate in sequence.

original: kartṛtvabhoktṛtvatatprayojakatvādayor bandhakāḥ /
translated: The qualities of being the doer, the experiencer, and the instigator of that are the causes of bondage.

original: anāsaktiśāntyādayo mocakāś ca prakṛter eva dharmāḥ /
analyzed: anāsakti śānti ādayaḥ mocakāḥ ca prakṛteḥ eva dharmāḥ
translated: Non-attachment, peace, etc. are the qualities of Prakṛti itself, which liberate.

original: kintu parameśvarasyāntaryāmitva eva prakṛtes te te dharmā udbudhyanta ity etadaṃśenaiva tasya prayojakatvam iti na tasya vaiṣamyanairghṛṇye
analyzed: kintu parameśvarasya antaryāmi tve eva prakṛteḥ te te dharmāḥ udbudhyante iti etad aṃśena eva tasya prayojaka tvam iti na tasya vaiṣamya nairghṛṇye
translated: But those qualities of Prakṛti manifest only in the Supreme Lord's state as the immanent one. To that extent, He is the instigator. Thus, He is not subject to inequality or cruelty.

original: baladevaḥ / vijñā na muhyantīty etad āha jñāneneti /🔽sarvaṃ jñānaplavenaiva Gītā / iti /
analyzed: baladevaḥ vijñāḥ na muhyanti iti etat āha jñānena iti  sarvam jñāna plavena eva gītā iti
translated: Baladeva. To explain that the wise do not become deluded, it is said by knowledge.🔽By the raft of knowledge alone (16.9) is stated in the Gita.

original: jñānāgniḥ sarvakarmāṇi Gītā / /
analyzed: jñāna agniḥ sarva karmāṇi gītā
translated: The fire of knowledge burns all actions (4.37) is stated in the Gita.

original: na hi jñānena sadṛśaṃ Gītā / iti coktamahimnā sadguruprasādalabdhena svaparātmaviṣayakena
analyzed: na hi jñānena sadṛśam gītāḥ iti ca ukta mahimnā sat guru prasāda labdhena sva para ātma viṣayakena
translated: For those good people who, by the knowledge obtained through the grace of a good guru, which has as its object their own and others' selves,

original: jñānena yeṣāṃ satprasaṅgināṃ tadvaimukhyam ajñānaṃ nāśitaṃ pradhvaṃsitaṃ teṣāṃ
analyzed: jñānena yeṣām sat prasaṅginām tad vaimukhyam ajñānam nāśitam pradhvaṃsitam teṣām
translated: have destroyed, annihilated, that ignorance which is aversion to that [knowledge],

original: tajjñānaṃ kartṛ paraṃ prakāśayati /
analyzed: tat jñānam kartṛ param prakāśayati
translated: that knowledge makes manifest the supreme [Self].

original: dehādeḥ paraṃ jīvaṃ vaiṣamyādidoṣāt param īśvaraṃ ca bodhayati /
analyzed: deha ādeḥ param jīvam vaiṣamya ādi doṣāt param īśvaram ca bodhayati
translated: It makes known the individual soul which is higher than the body etc., and God who is higher than the defects such as inequality etc.

original: ādityavat yathā ravir udita eva tamo nirasyan yathāvad vastu pradarśayati /
analyzed: āditya vat yathā raviḥ uditaḥ eva tamaḥ nirasyan yathāvat vastu pradarśayati
translated: Just as the sun, having risen, dispels darkness and reveals things as they are,

original: tathā sadgurūpadeśalabdham ātmajñānaṃ yathāvad ātmavastv iti /
analyzed: tathā sat guru upadeśa labdham ātma jñānam yathāvat ātma vastu iti
translated: in the same way, the knowledge of the Self obtained through the instruction of a good guru reveals the Self as it is.

original: atra vinaṣṭājñānānāṃ jīvānāṃ bahutvaṃ nigadatā pārthasārathinā mokṣe teṣāṃ taddarśitaṃ
analyzed: atra vinaṣṭa ajñānānām jīvānām bahu tvam nigadatā pārtha sārathinā mokṣe teṣām tat darśitam
translated: Here, by Partha-sarathi [Srimad-Bhagavad-gita], who mentions the plurality of individual souls whose ignorance has been destroyed, it is shown that they attain liberation.

original: aupādhikatvaṃ tasya praty uktaṃ neme janādhipāḥ ity upakramoktaṃ ca tat sopapattikam abhūt // //
analyzed: aupādhika tvam tasya prati uktam na ime janādhipāḥ iti upakrama uktam ca tat sa upapattikam abhūt
translated: The adventitious nature of that [ignorance] is stated. The statement made at the beginning, These are not kings, along with its reasoning, becomes valid.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: Bhagavad-gita

original: tadbuddhayas tadātmānas tanniṣṭhās tatparāyaṇāḥ /
analyzed: tad buddhayaḥ tad ātmānaḥ tad niṣṭhāḥ tad parāyaṇāḥ
translated: Those whose intellects are fixed on that, whose souls are absorbed in that, who are devoted to that,

original: gacchanty apunarāvṛttiṃ jñānanirdhūtakalmaṣāḥ ////
analyzed: gacchanti apunarāvṛttim jñāna nirdhūta kalmaṣāḥ
translated: they go to the state of non-return, their sins destroyed by knowledge.

original: śrīdharaḥ / evaṃbhūteśvaropāsakānāṃ phalam āha tadbuddhaya iti /🔽tasminn eva buddhir niścayātmikā yeṣām /
analyzed: āha          tasmin eva buddhiḥ niścaya ātmikā yeṣām
translated: Sridhara: The result for those who worship the Lord in this way is stated by tad-buddhayaḥ.🔽Those who have the firm conviction that He alone is all.

original: tasminn etātmā mano yeṣām /🔽tasminn eva niṣṭhā tātparyaṃ yeṣām /
analyzed: tasmin eta ātmā manaḥ yeṣām  tasmin eva niṣṭhā tātparyam yeṣām
translated: Those whose minds are fixed on Him alone.🔽Those who are intent on Him alone.

original: tad eva param ayamam āśrayo yeṣām /🔽tataś ca tatprasādalabdhenātmajñānena nirdhūtaṃ nirastaṃ kalmaṣaṃ yeṣām /
analyzed: tat eva param ayamam āśrayaḥ yeṣām  tatas ca tad prasāda labdhena ātma jñānena nirdhūtam nirastam kalmaṣam yeṣām
translated: Those who have Him alone as their supreme goal.🔽And those whose sins have been completely removed by the knowledge of the Self obtained through His grace.

original: te 'punarāvṛttiṃ muktiṃ yānti ////
analyzed: te punarāvṛttim muktim yānti
translated: They attain non-return, liberation.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana:

original: jñānena paramātmatattvaprakāśe sati tadbuddhaya iti /🔽tasmin jñānaprakāśite paramātmatattve saccidānandaghana eva bāhyasarvaviṣayaparityāgena
analyzed: jñānena paramātma tattva prakāśe sati tad buddhayaḥ iti  tasmin jñāna prakāśite paramātma tattve saccidānanda ghane eva bāhya sarva viṣaya parityāgena
translated: When the light of the truth of the Supreme Self is attained through knowledge, they are tad-buddhayaḥ.🔽In that Supreme Self, which is revealed by the light of knowledge, they have the firm conviction that He alone is the essence of existence, consciousness and bliss, by renouncing all external objects,

original: sādhanaparipākāt paryavasitā buddhir antaḥkaraṇavṛttiḥ sākṣātkāralakṣaṇā yeṣāṃ
analyzed: sādhana paripākāt paryavasitā buddhiḥ antaḥkaraṇa vṛttiḥ sākṣātkāra lakṣaṇā yeṣām
translated: and their internal organ, the mind, which is the function of the internal organ, has the nature of direct perception, and is complete due to the maturity of the means of knowledge.

original: te tadbuddhayaḥ sarvadā nirbījasamādhibhāja ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: te tad buddhayaḥ sarvadā nirbīja samādhi bhājaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Those who have this are tad-buddhayaḥ, always enjoyers of seedless samadhi, is the meaning.

original: tat kiṃ boddhāro jīvā boddhavyaṃ brahmatattvam iti boddhṛboddhavyabhāvo hi māyāvijṛmbhito na vāstavābhedavirodhīti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tat kim boddhāraḥ jīvāḥ boddhavyam brahma tattvam iti boddhṛ boddhavya bhāvaḥ hi māyā vijṛmbhitaḥ na vāstava abheda virodhi iti bhāvaḥ
translated: What is the meaning? The knowers are the individual souls, and Brahman is the truth to be known. Thus, the relation of knower and known is the manifestation of māyā, not contradictory to the real non-difference.

original: nanu tadātmāna iti viśeṣaṇaṃ vyartham /
analyzed: nanu tad ātmānaḥ iti viśeṣaṇam vyartham
translated: But the qualification they are of the nature of that is useless.

original: avidvadvyavartakaṃ hi vidvadviśeṣaṇam /
analyzed: a vidvat vyavartakam hi vidvat viśeṣaṇam
translated: For a qualification of the knower serves to exclude the ignorant.

original: ajñā api hi vastugatyā tadātmāna iti kathaṃ tadvyāvṛttir iti cet / na /
analyzed: ajñāḥ api hi vastu gatyā tad ātmānaḥ iti katham tad vyāvṛttiḥ iti ced na
translated: For even the ignorant, in reality, are of the nature of that. How then is there exclusion of them? If this is asked, no.

original: itarātmatvavyāvṛttau tātparyāt /
translated: Because the intention is in the exclusion of the nature of the other.

original: ajñā hi anātmabhūte dehādāv ātmābhimānina iti na tadātmāna iti vyapadiśyante /
analyzed: ajñāḥ hi anātma bhūte deha ādau ātma abhimāninaḥ iti na tad ātmānaḥ iti vyapadiśyante
translated: For the ignorant, who are attached to the non-Self such as the body, are not called they are of the nature of that, because they are attached to the non-Self.

original: vijñās tu nivṛttadehādyabhimānā iti virodhinivṛttyā tadātmāna iti vyapadiśyanta iti yuktaṃ viśeṣaṇam /
analyzed: vijñāḥ tu nivṛtta deha ādi abhimānāḥ iti virodhi nivṛttyā tad ātmānaḥ iti vyapadiśyante iti yuktam viśeṣaṇam
translated: But the wise, having abandoned the notion of the body etc., are called they are of the nature of that by the cessation of the contrary. Thus the qualification is proper.

original: nanu karmānuṣṭhānavikṣepe sati kathaṃ dehādyabhimānanivṛttir iti tatrāha tanniṣṭhā iti /
analyzed: nanu karma anuṣṭhāna vikṣepe sati katham deha ādi abhimāna nivṛttiḥ iti tatra āha tad niṣṭhāḥ iti
translated: But if there is distraction due to the performance of rites and duties, how can there be cessation of the notion of the body etc.? In this regard, he says they are devoted to that.

original: tasminn eva brahmaṇi sarvakarmānuṣṭhānavikṣepanivṛttyā niṣṭhā sthitir yeṣāṃ te tanniṣṭhāḥ /
analyzed: tasmin eva brahmaṇi sarva karma anuṣṭhāna vikṣepa nivṛttyā niṣṭhā sthitiḥ yeṣām te tad niṣṭhāḥ
translated: Those who, by the cessation of distraction due to the performance of all rites and duties, are devoted to, established in, Brahman alone, they are devoted to that.

original: sarvakarmasaṃnyāsena tadekavicāraparā ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: sarva karma saṃnyāsena tad eka vicāra parāḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: they are intent on that alone, i.e., on the one consideration, by renouncing all actions.

original: phalarāge sati kathaṃ tatsādhanabhūtakarmatyāga iti tatrāha tatparāyaṇāḥ /
analyzed: phala rāge sati katham tad sādhana bhūta karma tyāgaḥ iti tatra āha tad parāyaṇāḥ
translated: When there is attachment to the result, how can there be renunciation of the actions that are the means to that? There, he says: intent on that.

original: tad eva param ayanaṃ prāptavyaṃ yeṣāṃ te tatparāyaṇāḥ /
analyzed: tat eva param ayanam prāptavyam yeṣām te tad parāyaṇāḥ
translated: Those for whom that alone is the supreme goal are intent on that.

original: sarvato viraktā ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: sarvatas viraktāḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: detached from everything.

original: atra tadbuddhaya ity anena sākṣātkāra uktaḥ /
analyzed: atra tad buddhayaḥ iti anena sākṣātkāraḥ uktaḥ
translated: Here, by the words with that thought, direct realization is stated.

original: tadātmāna ity anātmābhimārūpaviparītabhāvanivṛttiphalako vedāntavicāraḥ śravaṇamananaparipākarūpaḥ /
analyzed: tad ātmānaḥ iti vedānta vicāraḥ śravaṇa manana paripāka rūpaḥ
translated: By the words with that as their Self, the inquiry into the Vedanta, which has the result of the cessation of the inverted conception of the form of the non-Self that is conceived as the Self, and which consists of the maturity of hearing and reflection, is stated.

original: tatparāyaṇā ity anena vairāgyaprakarṣaṃ ity uttarottarasya pūrvapūrvahetutvaṃ draṣṭavyam /
analyzed: tad parāyaṇāḥ iti anena vairāgya prakarṣam iti uttara uttarasya pūrva pūrva hetu tvam draṣṭavyam
translated: By the words intent on that, the excellence of detachment is stated. Thus, it should be seen that each subsequent one is the cause of the preceding one.

original: uktaviśeṣaṇā yatayo gacchanty apunarāvṛttiṃ punardehasambandhābhāvarūpāṃ muktiṃ prāpnuvanti /
analyzed: ukta viśeṣaṇāḥ yatayaḥ gacchanti apunarāvṛttim punar deha sambandha abhāva rūpām muktim prāpnuvanti
translated: The ascetics with the aforementioned qualifications go to the state of non-return, i.e., attain liberation, which consists of the absence of connection with the body again.

original: sakṛn muktānām api punar dehasambandhaḥ kuto na syād iti tatrāha jñānanirdhūtakalmaṣāḥ
analyzed: sakṛt muktānām api punar deha sambandhaḥ kutas na syāt iti tatra āha jñāna nirdhūta kalmaṣāḥ
translated: How can there be a connection with the body again even for those who are liberated once? There, he says: with their sins destroyed by knowledge.

original: jñānena nirdhūtaṃ samūlam unmūlitaṃ punardehasambandhakāraṇaṃ kalmaṣaṃ puṇyapāpātmakaṃ
analyzed: jñānena nirdhūtam sa mūlam unmūlitam punar deha sambandha kāraṇam kalmaṣam puṇya pāpa ātmakam
translated: The word 'punah' (again) is used to indicate that the root of the bondage of the body is the sin consisting of merit and demerit, which is uprooted by knowledge.

original: karma yeṣāṃ te tathā /
analyzed: karma yeṣām te tathā
translated: Those who have destroyed that sin are called 'punar dehâbhāginah'.

original: jñānenānādyajñānanivṛttyā tatkāryakarmakṣaye tanmūlakaṃ punar dehagrahaṇaṃ kathaṃ bhaved iti bhāvaḥ ////
translated: The idea is: how can there be a further taking up of the body, which is rooted in that (sin), by the destruction of the actions caused by that (sin), through the cessation of the beginningless ignorance by knowledge?

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha:

original: kintu vidyā jīvātmajñānam eva prakāśayati /
analyzed: kintu vidyā jīvātma jñānam eva prakāśayati
translated: But knowledge only reveals the knowledge of the individual self.

original: na tu paramātmajñānaṃ bhaktyāham ekayā grāhyaḥ iti bhagavadukteḥ /
analyzed: na tu paramātma jñānam bhaktyā aham ekayā grāhyaḥ iti bhagavat ukteḥ
translated: Not the knowledge of the Supreme Self, because of the statement of the Lord: I am to be apprehended by single devotion.

original: tasmāt paramātmajñānārthaṃ jñānibhir api punar viśeṣato bhaktiḥ kāryā ity ata āha tadbuddhaya iti /
analyzed: tasmāt paramātma jñāna artham jñānibhiḥ api punar viśeṣataḥ bhaktiḥ kāryā iti atas āha tad buddhayaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, even the knowers of Brahman should perform devotion especially for the knowledge of the Supreme Self. With this in mind, the Lord says: 'Tad-buddhaya' etc.

original: tatpadena pūrvam upakrānto vibhuḥ parāmṛśyate /🔽tasmin parameśvara eva buddhir yeṣām te tammananaparā ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: tad padena pūrvam upakrāntaḥ vibhuḥ parāmṛśyate  tasmin parameśvaraḥ eva buddhiḥ yeṣām te tad manana parāḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The word 'tat' (that) refers to the all-pervading Supreme Self mentioned earlier.🔽Those whose intellect is fixed on Him are called 'tad-buddhaya'. The meaning is: they are intent on meditating on Him.

original: tadātmānas tanmanaskās tam eva dhyāyanta ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: tad ātmānaḥ tad manaskāḥ tam eva dhyāyantaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: their souls are fixed on Him, their minds are fixed on Him, they meditate on Him alone.

original: tanniṣṭhāḥ jñānaṃ mayi saṃnyaset iti bhagavadukteḥ /
translated: They are devoted to Him, because of the statement of the Lord: One should surrender the knowledge into Me.

original: dehādyatiriktātmmajñāne 'pi sāttvike niṣṭhāṃ parityajya tadekaniṣṭhāḥ /
analyzed: deha ādi atirikta ātmma jñāne sāttvike niṣṭhām parityajya tad eka niṣṭhāḥ
translated: Even in the knowledge of the Self as distinct from the body etc., which is of the sattva quality, they abandon attachment to that and become solely devoted to that.

original: tatparāyaṇās tadīyaśravaṇakīrtanaparāḥ /
analyzed: tad parāyaṇāḥ tadīya śravaṇa kīrtana parāḥ
translated: They are intent on that, devoted to hearing and glorifying it.

original: yad vakṣyate
analyzed: yat vakṣyate
translated: As will be said:

original: bhaktyā mām abhijānāti yāvān yaś cāsmi tattvataḥ /
analyzed: bhaktyā mām abhijānāti yāvān yaḥ ca asmi tattvataḥ
translated: By devotion one knows Me as I really am, in all My extent and nature.

original: tato māṃ tattvato jñātvā viśate tadanantaram // Gītā / iti /
analyzed: tatas mām tattvataḥ jñātvā viśate tad anantaram gītāḥ iti
translated: Then, having known Me as I really am, one enters into Me afterwards. (Gita)

original: jñānanirdhūtakalmaṣā jñānena vidyāyaiva pūrvam eva dhvastasamastāvidyāḥ ////
analyzed: jñāna nirdhūta kalmaṣāḥ jñānena vidyāya eva pūrvam eva dhvasta samasta avidyāḥ
translated: Their impurities are removed by knowledge, their ignorance is completely destroyed by knowledge itself from the very beginning.

original: baladevaḥ / paramātmany avaiṣamyādidhyāyatāṃ phalam āha tad iti /
translated: Balarama. For those who meditate on the Supreme Self as free from inequality etc., the result is stated by tat (in the verse).

original: tasmiṃs tadavaiṣamyādike guṇagaṇe buddhir niścayātmikā yeṣāṃ te /
analyzed: tasmin tad avaiṣamya ādike guṇa gaṇe buddhiḥ niścaya ātmikā yeṣām te
translated: Those who have the firm conviction that the Supreme Self is free from inequality etc. are te (those who have the firm conviction).

original: tadātmānas tasmin niviṣṭamanasaḥ tanniṣṭhās tattātparyavantas tatparāyaṇās tatsamāśrayāḥ /
analyzed: tad ātmānaḥ tasmin niviṣṭa manasaḥ tad niṣṭhāḥ tad tātparyavantaḥ tad parāyaṇāḥ tad samāśrayāḥ
translated: Tadatmanah (those who have fixed their minds on that) means those who have fixed their minds on that, those who are devoted to that, those who are intent on that, those who are devoted to that.

original: evam abhyastena tadvaiṣamyādiguṇajñānena nirdhūtakalmaṣā vinaṣṭatadvaimukhyāḥ santa apunarāvṛttiṃ muktiṃ gacchantīti ////
analyzed: evam abhyastena tad vaiṣamya ādi guṇa jñānena nirdhūta kalmaṣāḥ vinaṣṭa tad vaimukhyāḥ santa apunarāvṛttim muktim gacchanti iti
translated: Thus, by the knowledge of the qualities of that, such as freedom from inequality etc., which is practiced in this way, their impurities are removed, their aversion to that is destroyed, and they attain liberation, which is non-return.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: (Gita 9.30)

original: vidyāvinayasaṃpanne brāhmaṇe gavi hastini /
analyzed: vidyā vinaya saṃpanne brāhmaṇe gavi hastini
translated: In a learned and humble Brahmin, in a cow, in an elephant,

original: śuni caiva śvapāke ca paṇḍitāḥ samadarśinaḥ ////
analyzed: śuni ca eva śvapāke ca paṇḍitāḥ sama darśinaḥ
translated: And in a dog and an outcaste, the wise ones see equally.

original: śrīdharaḥ / kīdṛśās te jñānino ye 'punarāvṛttiṃ gacchantīty apekṣāyām āha vidyāvinayasaṃpanna iti /
translated: Śrīdhara: What kind of knowers of the Self go to non-return? In response to this question, it is said: endowed with knowledge and humility.

original: viṣameṣv api samaṃ brahmaiva draṣṭuṃ śīlaṃ yeṣāṃ te paṇḍitāḥ /
analyzed: viṣameṣu api samam brahma eva draṣṭum śīlam yeṣām te paṇḍitāḥ
translated: Those who have the habit of seeing Brahman equally even in the uneven are the wise.

original: jñānina ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: jñāninaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: knowers of the Self.

original: atra vidyāvinayābhyāṃ yukte brāhmaṇe ca /
analyzed: atra vidyā vinayābhyām yukte brāhmaṇe ca
translated: Here, in a Brahmin endowed with knowledge and humility,

original: śuno yaḥ pacati tasmin śvapāke ca iti karmaṇā vaiṣamyam /
analyzed: śunaḥ yaḥ pacati tasmin śvapāke ca iti karmaṇā vaiṣamyam
translated: and in a dog-cook, an outcaste, there is unevenness due to action.

original: gavi hastini śuni ceti jātito vaiṣamyaṃ darśitam ////
analyzed: gavi hastini śuni ca iti jātitaḥ vaiṣamyam darśitam
translated: And in a cow, an elephant, and a dog, unevenness due to species is shown.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusūdana:

original: dehapātād ūrdhvaṃ videhakaivalyarūpaṃ jñānaphalam uktvā prārabdhakarmavaśāt saty api dehe jīvanmuktirūpaṃ tatphalam āha vidyeti /
analyzed: dehapātāt ūrdhvam videha kaivalya rūpam jñāna phalam uktvā prārabdha karma vaśāt sati api dehe jīvanmukti rūpam tad phalam āha vidyā iti
translated: Having described the fruit of knowledge as being the form of bodyless liberation after the fall of the body, he says the fruit of knowledge in the form of jīvanmukti even with the body due to the power of prārabdha karma: by knowledge, etc.

original: vidyā vedārthaparijñānaṃ brahmavidyā vā /
analyzed: vidyā veda artha parijñānam brahma vidyā vā
translated: Knowledge is the thorough understanding of the meaning of the Vedas or the knowledge of Brahman.

original: vinayo nirahaṅkāratvam anauddhatyam iti yāvat /
analyzed: vinayaḥ nirahaṅkāra tvam anauddhatyam iti yāvat
translated: Humility is the absence of egotism, as far as lack of haughtiness is concerned.

original: tābhyāṃ saṃpanne brahmavidi vinīte ca brāhmaṇe sāttvike sarvottame /
analyzed: tābhyām saṃpanne brahma vidi vinīte ca brāhmaṇe sāttvike sarva uttame
translated: In a Brahmin who is endowed with these two, who knows Brahman and is humble, who is of the sāttvika quality and is the best of all,

original: tathā gavi saṃskārahīnāyāṃ rājasyāṃ madhyamāyāṃ /
analyzed: tathā gavi saṃskāra hīnāyām rājasyām madhyamāyām
translated: Similarly, in a cow, which is of the Rajas quality, and is middling, and is devoid of embellishments.

original: tathā hastini śuni śvapāke cātyanta tāmase sarvādhame 'pi /
analyzed: tathā hastini śuni śvapāke ca atyanta tāmase sarva adhame
translated: Similarly, in an elephant, a dog, and an outcaste, who are of the Tamas quality, and are the most inferior of all.

original: sattvādiguṇais tajjaiś ca saṃskārair aspṛṣṭam eva samaṃ brahma draṣṭuṃ śīlaṃ yeṣāṃ te samadarśinaḥ /
analyzed: sattva ādi guṇaiḥ tad jaiḥ ca saṃskāraiḥ a spṛṣṭam eva samam brahma draṣṭum śīlam yeṣām te sama darśinaḥ
translated: Those who have the habit of seeing Brahman as the same, untouched by the qualities of Sattva etc. and by the embellishments born of them, they are the seers of equality.

original: paṇḍitā jñāninaḥ /
analyzed: paṇḍitāḥ jñāninaḥ
translated: The wise ones, the knowers of Brahman.

original: yathā gaṅgātoye taḍāge surāyāṃ mūtre vā pratibimbitasyādityasya na tadguṇadoṣasambandhas
analyzed: yathā gaṅgā toye taḍāge surāyām mūtre vā pratibimbitasya ādityasya na tad guṇa doṣa sambandhaḥ
translated: Just as the sun reflected in the water of the Ganges, in a pond, in liquor, or in urine, is not connected with their good or bad qualities,

original: tathā brahmaṇo 'pi cidābhāsadvārā pratibimbitasya nopādhigataguṇadoṣasambandha
analyzed: tathā brahmaṇaḥ pi cit ābhāsa dvārā pratibimbitasya na upādhi gata guṇa doṣa sambandha
translated: in the same way, Brahman, which is reflected through the medium of the light of consciousness, is not connected with the good or bad qualities of the limiting adjuncts.

original: iti pratisandadhānāḥ
analyzed: iti pratisandadhānāḥ
translated: Thus reflecting,

original: sarvatra samadṛṣṭyaiva rāgadveṣarāhityena paramānandasphūrtyā jīvanmuktim anubhavantīty arthaḥ ////
analyzed: sarvatra sama dṛṣṭyā eva rāga dveṣa rāhityena paramānanda sphūrtyā jīvanmuktim anubhavanti iti arthaḥ
translated: they experience, by the vision of equality everywhere, the state of being a living liberated soul, by the manifestation of supreme bliss, due to the absence of attachment and aversion. This is the meaning.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha.

original: tataś ca guṇātītānāṃ teṣāṃ guṇamaye vastumātra eva tāratamyamayaṃ viśeṣam ajighṛkṣūṇāṃ samabuddhir eva syād ity āha vidyeti /
analyzed: tatas ca guṇa atītānām teṣām guṇa maye vastu mātre eva tāratamya mayam viśeṣam ajighṛkṣūṇām sama buddhiḥ eva syāt iti āha vidyā iti
translated: And therefore, for them who have gone beyond the qualities, and who do not desire even the difference consisting in the gradation of objects consisting of the qualities, there would be only equanimity of mind. Thus it is said: By knowledge etc.

original: brāhmaṇe gavīti sāttvikajātitvāt /
analyzed: brāhmaṇe gavi iti sāttvika jāti tvāt
translated: In a Brahmana, in a cow, because of the quality of being of the Sattva quality.

original: hastini madhyame /
analyzed: hastini madhyame
translated: In the elephant, in the middle.

original: śuni ca śvapāke ceti tāmasjātitvād adhame 'pi tattadviśeṣāgrahaṇāt samadarśinaḥ paṇḍitā guṇātītāḥ /
analyzed: śuni ca śvapāke ca iti tāmaḥ jāti tvāt adhame pi tad tad viśeṣa agrahaṇāt sama darśinaḥ paṇḍitāḥ guṇa atītāḥ
translated: And in the dog, and in the Chandala, thus, even in the lowest, due to having the Tamas-type of birth, those who see equally, the wise, are beyond qualities.

original: viśeṣāgrahaṇam eva samaṃ guṇātītaṃ brahma /
analyzed: viśeṣa agrahaṇam eva samam guṇa atītam brahma
translated: The very equality of not grasping distinctions is Brahman, which is beyond qualities.

original: tad draṣṭuṃ śīlaṃ yeṣāṃ te ////
analyzed: tat draṣṭum śīlam yeṣām te
translated: Those who have the habit of seeing that are...

original: baladevaḥ / tān stauti vidyeti /
analyzed: baladevaḥ tān stauti vidyā iti
translated: Balarama. He praises them with vidya etc.

original: tādṛśe brāhmaṇe śvapāke ceti karmaṇaitau viṣamau gavi hastini śuni ceti jātyaite viṣamāḥ /
analyzed: tādṛśe brāhmaṇe śvapāke ca iti karmaṇā etau viṣamau gavi hastini śuni ca iti jātyā ete viṣamāḥ
translated: In such a Brahmin and in a Chandala, these two are unequal due to their actions; in a cow, an elephant, and a dog, these are unequal due to their species.

original: evaṃ viṣamatayā sṛṣṭeṣu brāhmaṇādiṣu ye paramātmānaṃ samaṃ paśyanti /
analyzed: evam viṣama tayā sṛṣṭeṣu brāhmaṇa ādiṣu ye paramātmānam samam paśyanti
translated: Thus, among Brahmins etc. created unequally, those who see the Supreme Self as equal,

original: ta eva paṇḍitāḥ /
analyzed: te eva paṇḍitāḥ
translated: they alone are wise.

original: tatkarmānusāriṇī tena teṣāṃ tathā tathā sṛṣṭiḥ /
analyzed: tad karma anusāriṇī tena teṣām tathā tathā sṛṣṭiḥ
translated: Their creation is in accordance with their actions, thus by Him.

original: na tu rāgadveṣānusāriṇīti parjanyavat sarvatra samaḥ paramātmeti ////🔽BhG /
analyzed: na tu rāga dveṣa anusāriṇī iti parjanya vat sarvatra samaḥ paramātmā iti  bhg
translated: It is not in accordance with attachment and aversion. Thus, the Supreme Self is equal everywhere, like the rain-bearing cloud.

original: ihaiva tair jitaḥ sargo yeṣāṃ sāmye sthitaṃ manaḥ /
analyzed: iha eva taiḥ jitaḥ sargaḥ yeṣām sāmye sthitam manaḥ
translated: In this very world, those whose minds are established in equality have conquered birth.

original: nirdoṣaṃ hi samaṃ brahma tasmād brahmaṇi te sthitāḥ ////
analyzed: nirdoṣam hi samam brahma tasmāt brahmaṇi te sthitāḥ
translated: For Brahman is indeed faultless and equal. Therefore, they abide in Brahman.

original: śrīdharaḥ / nanu viṣamesu samadarśanaṃ niṣiddhaṃ kurvanto 'pi kathaṃ te paṇḍitāḥ /
translated: Sridhara: But how can they be wise, even though they do what is forbidden, namely, seeing equality in what is unequal?

original: yathāha gautamaḥ samāsam ābhyāṃ viṣamasame pūjātaḥ iti /
analyzed: yathā āha gautamaḥ samāsam ābhyām viṣama same pūjātaḥ iti
translated: As Gautama says: By these two, in the unequal and equal, from worship.

original: asyārthaḥ samāya pūjayā viṣame prakāre kṛte sati viṣamāya ca same prakāre kṛte sati sa pūjaka iha lokāt paralokāc ca hīyata iti /
analyzed: asya arthaḥ samāya pūjayā viṣame prakāre kṛte sati viṣamāya ca same prakāre kṛte sati sa pūjakaḥ iha lokāt para lokāt ca hīyate iti
translated: The meaning is: when worship is done in an unequal way, and when an equal way is done in an unequal way, that worshipper is deprived of this world and the next world.

original: tatrāha ihaiveti /
analyzed: tatra āha iha eva iti
translated: There it is said even here (in this world).

original: ihaiva jīvadbhir eva taiḥ /
analyzed: iha eva jīvadbhiḥ eva taiḥ
translated: Even by those who are alive here,

original: sṛjyate iti sargaḥ saṃsāraḥ /
analyzed: sṛjyate iti sargaḥ saṃsāraḥ
translated: creation is the world of transmigration.

original: jito nirastaḥ /
analyzed: jitaḥ nirastaḥ
translated: Conquered, set aside.

original: kaiḥ / yeṣāṃ manaḥ sāmye samatve sthitaṃ /
analyzed: kaiḥ yeṣām manaḥ sāmye samatve sthitam
translated: By whom? By those whose mind abides in equality, in sameness.

original: tatra hetuḥ hi yasmād brahma samaṃ nirdoṣaṃ ca tasmāt te samadarśino brahmaṇy eva sthitāḥ /
analyzed: tatra hetuḥ hi yasmāt brahma samam nirdoṣam ca tasmāt te sama darśinaḥ brahmaṇi eva sthitāḥ
translated: The reason for that is: because Brahman is equal and faultless, therefore they, seeing equality, abide in Brahman itself.

original: brahmabhāvaṃ prāptā ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: brahma bhāvam prāptāḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: they have attained the state of Brahman.

original: gautamoktas tu doṣo brahmabhāvaprāpteḥ pūrvam eva /
analyzed: gautama uktaḥ tu doṣaḥ brahma bhāva prāpteḥ pūrvam eva
translated: But the fault stated by Gautama is before the attainment of the state of Brahman,

original: pūjāta iti pūjakāvasthāśravaṇāt ////
analyzed: pūjātaḥ iti pūjaka avasthā śravaṇāt
translated: because from worship is heard in the state of the worshipper.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana:

original: nanu sāttvikarājasatāmaseṣu svabhāvaviṣameṣu prāṇiṣu samatvadarśanaṃ dharmaśāstraniṣiddham /
analyzed: nanu sāttvika rājasa tāmaseṣu svabhāva viṣameṣu prāṇiṣu samatva darśanam dharma śāstra niṣiddham
translated: But the view of equality towards beings whose natures are uneven, being of the sattva, rajas, and tamas qualities, is prohibited by the Dharma Shastras.

original: tathā ca tasyānnam abhojyam ity upakramya gautamaḥ smarati samāsam ābhyāṃ viṣamasame pūjāta iti /
analyzed: tathā ca tasya annam abhojyam iti upakramya gautamaḥ smarati samāsam ābhyām viṣama same pūjātaḥ iti
translated: And in this way, Gautama, having begun with His food is not to be eaten, remembers: With these two equally, with the uneven and the equal, in the worship.

original: samāsam ābhyām iti caturthīdvivacanam /
analyzed: samāsam ābhyām iti caturthī dvivacanam
translated: And with these two is the dual of the fourth case.

original: viṣamasama iti dvandvaikavad bhāvena saptamyekavacanam /🔽caturvedapāragāṇām atyantasadācārāṇāṃ yādṛśo vastrālaṅkārānnādidānapuraḥsaraḥ
analyzed: viṣama samaḥ iti dvandva eka vat bhāvena saptamī ekavacanam  catur veda pāragāṇām atyanta sat ācārāṇām yādṛśaḥ vastra alaṅkāra anna ādi dāna puraḥsaraḥ
translated: Uneven and equal is the singular of the seventh case by the rule of the dvandva compound having the form of the singular.🔽The special worship with the giving of clothes, ornaments, food, etc.

original: pūjāviśesaḥ kriyate tatsamāyaivānyasmai caturvedapāragāya sadācārāya viṣame tadapekṣayā🔽nyūne pūjāprakāre kṛte /🔽tathālpavedānāṃ hīnācārāṇāṃ yādṛśo hīnasādhanaḥ pūjāprakāraḥ kriyate tādṛśāyaivāsamāya
analyzed: pūjā viśesaḥ kriyate tad samāya eva anyasmai catur veda pāragāya sat ācārāya viṣame tad apekṣayā  nyūne pūjā prakāre kṛte  tathā alpa vedānām hīna ācārāṇām yādṛśaḥ hīna sādhanaḥ pūjā prakāraḥ kriyate tādṛśāya eva asamāya
translated: that is done to one who has mastered the four Vedas and has extremely good conduct, is equal to that very same worship to another who has mastered the four Vedas and has good conduct, when the form of worship is done unevenly, less in comparison to that.🔽And the form of worship with inferior means that is done to those who have little knowledge and bad conduct, is equal to that very same worship

original: pūrvoktavedapāragasadācārabrāhmaṇāpekṣayā hīnāya tādṛśahīnapūjādhike mukhyapūjāsame pūjāprakāre
analyzed: pūrva ukta vedapāraga sat ācāra brāhmaṇa apekṣayā hīnāya tādṛśa hīna pūjā adhike mukhya pūjā same pūjā prakāre
translated: to one who is inferior in comparison to the Brahmin mentioned earlier who has mastered the Vedas and has good conduct, when the form of worship is done with more of the inferior worship and is equal to the principal worship.

original: kṛte / uttamasya hīnatayā hīnasyottamatayā pūjāto hetos tasya pūjayitur annam abhojyaṃ bhavatīty arthaḥ /
analyzed: kṛte uttamasya hīna tayā hīnasya uttama tayā pūjātaḥ hetoḥ tasya pūjayituḥ annam abhojyam bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: In the Kṛta age, the food of the worshipper becomes uneatable, i.e. it becomes unfit to be eaten, on account of the worship, by reason of the superiority of the superior and the inferiority of the inferior.

original: pūjayitā pratipattiviśesam akurvan dhanād dharmāc ca hīyata iti ca doṣāntaram /
analyzed: pūjayitā pratipatti viśesam a kurvan dhanāt dharmāt ca hīyate iti ca doṣa antaram
translated: And the worshipper, not performing the special practice, falls away from wealth and from dharma—this is another fault.

original: yadyapi yatīnāṃ niṣparigrahāṇāṃ pākābhāvād dhanābhāvāc cābhojyānnatvaṃ dhanahīnatvaṃ ca svata eva vidyate tathāpi dharmahānir doso bhavaty 🔽eva /
analyzed: yadi api yatīnām niṣparigrahāṇām pāka abhāvāt dhana abhāvāt ca abhojya anna tvam dhana hīna tvam ca svatas eva vidyate tathā api dharma hāniḥ dosaḥ bhavati  eva
translated: Even though, for ascetics who have no possessions and who have no cooking, the condition of having uneatable food and the condition of being poor are present by themselves, still the loss of dharma is a fault.

original: abhojyānnatvaṃ cāśucitvena pāptpattyupalakṣaṇam /
analyzed: abhojya anna tvam ca aśuci tvena
translated: And the condition of having uneatable food is an indication of the attainment of impurity.🔽And for those whose wealth is austerity, austerity itself is wealth, so the loss of that is also a fault.

original: tapodhanānāṃ ca tapa eva dhanam iti taddhānir api dūṣaṇaṃ bhavaty eveti kathaṃ samadarśinaḥ paṇḍitā jīvanmuktā iti prāpte pariharati ihaiveti
analyzed: tapodhanānām ca tapaḥ eva dhanam iti tad hāniḥ api dūṣaṇam bhavati eva iti katham sama darśinaḥ paṇḍitāḥ jīvanmuktāḥ iti prāpte pariharati iha eva iti
translated: So, when it is argued that how can the wise, the liberated while living, be impartial, he replies: iha eva, even here.

original: taiḥ samadarśibhiḥ paṇḍitair ihaiva jīvanadaśāyām eva jito 'tikrāntaḥ sargaḥ sṛjyata iti vyutpattyā dvaitaprapañcaḥ /
analyzed: taiḥ sama darśibhiḥ paṇḍitaiḥ iha eva jīvana daśāyām eva sargaḥ sṛjyate iti vyutpattyā dvaita prapañcaḥ
translated: By them, the impartial, the wise, even here, in the state of life, the creation, the world of duality, is conquered, is transcended, by the derivation of the word sarga as that which is created.

original: dehapātād ūrdhvam atikramitavya iti kim u vaktavyam /
analyzed: dehapātāt ūrdhvam atikramitavyaḥ iti kim u vaktavyam
translated: What need be said about the necessity of transcending it after the fall of the body?

original: kaiḥ /
analyzed: kaiḥ
translated: By whom?

original: yeṣāṃ sāmye sarvabhūteṣu viṣameṣv api vartamānasya brahmaṇaḥ samabhāve sthitaṃ niścalaṃ manaḥ /
analyzed: yeṣām sāmye sarva bhūteṣu viṣameṣu api vartamānasya brahmaṇaḥ sama bhāve sthitam niścalam manaḥ
translated: For those whose mind is fixed, unmoved, in the equality of Brahman, which exists in all beings, even in unequal ones.

original: hi yasmān nirdoṣaṃ samaṃ sarvavikāraśūnyaṃ kūṭasthanityam ekaṃ ca brahma tasmāt te brahmaṇy eva sthitāḥ /
analyzed: hi yasmāt nirdoṣam samam sarva vikāra śūnyam kūṭastha nityam ekam ca brahma tasmāt te brahmaṇi eva sthitāḥ
translated: Since Brahman is thus faultless, equal, devoid of all modifications, immutable, and one, therefore they abide in Brahman alone.

original: ayaṃ bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: ayam bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is this.

original: duṣṭatvam hi dvedhā bhavati aduṣṭasyāpi duṣṭasambandhāt svato duṣṭatvād vā /
analyzed: duṣṭa tvam hi dvedhā bhavati aduṣṭasya api duṣṭa sambandhāt svatas duṣṭa tvāt vā
translated: For impurity can be of two kinds: even that which is not impure becomes impure due to contact with the impure, or it is impure by its own nature.

original: yathā gaṅgodakasya mūtragartapātāt /
analyzed: yathā gaṅgā udakasya mūtra garta pātāt
translated: Like the water of the Ganges, due to falling into a pit of urine.

original: svata eva vā yathā mūtrādeḥ /
analyzed: svatas eva vā yathā mūtra ādeḥ
translated: Or it is impure by its own nature, like urine and so on.

original: tatra doṣavatsu śvapākādiṣu sthitaṃ doṣair duṣyati brahmeti mūḍhair vibhāvyamānam api sarvadoṣāsaṃsṛṣṭam eva brahma vyomavad asaṅgatvāt /
analyzed: tatra doṣavatsu śvapāka ādiṣu sthitam doṣaiḥ duṣyati brahma iti mūḍhaiḥ vibhāvyamānam api sarva doṣa asaṃsṛṣṭam eva brahma vyoma vat asaṅga tvāt
translated: There, Brahman, even though imagined by the deluded as becoming impure due to contact with faults while dwelling in the faulty, such as the outcaste, is itself untouched by all faults, like the sky, due to being unattached.

original: asaṅgo hy ayaṃ puruṣaḥ /
analyzed: a saṅgaḥ hi ayam puruṣaḥ
translated: For this person is unattached.

original: sūryo yathā sarvalokasya cakṣur
analyzed: sūryaḥ yathā sarva lokasya cakṣuḥ
translated: Just as the sun is the eye of all the world,

original: na lipyate cākṣuṣair bāhyadoṣaiḥ /
analyzed: na lipyate cākṣuṣaiḥ bāhya doṣaiḥ
translated: and is not tainted by external faults of the eye,

original: ekas tathā sarvabhūtāntarātmā
analyzed: ekaḥ tathā sarva bhūta antarātmā
translated: in the same way, the one inner self of all beings,🔽is not tainted by external worldly suffering.

original: na lipyate lokaduḥkhena bāhyaḥ // iti śruteḥ /
analyzed: na lipyate loka duḥkhena bāhyaḥ iti śruteḥ
translated: Thus it is heard.

original: nāpi kāmādidharmavattayā svata eva kaluṣitaṃ kāmāder antaḥkaraṇadharmatvasya śrutismṛtisiddhatvāt /
analyzed: nā api kāma ādi dharmavat tayā svatas eva kaluṣitam kāma ādeḥ antaḥkaraṇa dharma tvasya śruti smṛti siddha tvāt
translated: Nor is it defiled by itself by having the qualities of desire etc., because the fact that desire etc. are qualities of the internal organ is established by the Vedas and Smritis.

original: tasmān nirdoṣabrahmarūpā yatayo jīvanmuktā abhojyānnādidoṣaduṣṭāś ceti vyāhṛtam /
analyzed: tasmāt nirdoṣa brahma rūpāḥ yatayaḥ jīvanmuktāḥ abhojya anna ādi doṣa duṣṭāḥ ca iti vyāhṛtam
translated: Therefore, it is said that the liberated ascetics, who are of the nature of faultless Brahman, are not defiled by the faults of eating forbidden food etc.

original: smṛtis tv avidvadgṛhasthaviṣayaiva /
analyzed: smṛtiḥ tu avidvat gṛhastha viṣayā eva
translated: But the Smriti refers only to the ignorant householder.

original: tasyānnabhojyam ity upakramāt /
analyzed: tasya anna bhojyam iti upakramāt
translated: Because it begins with His food is not to be eaten.

original: pūjāta iti madhye nirdeśāt /
analyzed: pūjātaḥ iti madhye nirdeśāt
translated: And because it is mentioned in the middle as from worship,

original: dhanād dharmāc ca hīyata ity upasaṃhārāc ceti draṣṭavyam ////
analyzed: dhanāt dharmāt ca hīyate iti upasaṃhārāt ca iti draṣṭavyam
translated: and because it concludes with he falls from wealth and dharma.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha.

original: samadṛṣṭitvaṃ stauti /
analyzed: sama dṛṣṭi tvam stauti
translated: He praises the state of having an equal vision.

original: ihaiva iha loka eva sṛjyata iti sargaḥ saṃsāro jitaḥ parābhūtaḥ ////
analyzed: iha eva iha lokaḥ eva sṛjyate iti sargaḥ saṃsāraḥ jitaḥ parābhūtaḥ
translated: In this very world - the creation, the worldly existence, is conquered, overcome, by them.

original: baladevaḥ / iheti /
analyzed: baladevaḥ iha iti
translated: Balarama. In this etc.

original: iha sādhanadaśāyām eva taiḥ sargaḥ saṃsāro jitaḥ parābhūtaḥ /
analyzed: iha sādhana daśāyām eva taiḥ sargaḥ saṃsāraḥ jitaḥ parābhūtaḥ
translated: By them, the creation, the worldly existence, is conquered, overcome, in this very stage of spiritual practice.

original: kaiḥ / yeṣāṃ manaḥ sāmye 'vaiṣamyākhye brahmadharme sthitaṃ niviṣṭam /
analyzed: kaiḥ yeṣām manaḥ sāmye vaiṣamya ākhye brahma dharme sthitam niviṣṭam
translated: By whom? By those whose mind is fixed, settled, in the quality of Brahman called equality, non-discrimination.

original: kuto brahmāviṣamam /
analyzed: kutas brahma aviṣamam
translated: Why is Brahman non-discriminating?

original: tatrāha nirdoṣaṃ hīti /
analyzed: tatra āha nirdoṣam hi iti
translated: To that he says because it is faultless.

original: hi yato brahmaṇy avaiṣamyādikaṃ niścikyus tasmāt prapañce tiṣṭhanto 'pi te brahmaṇy eva sthitāḥ muktis teṣāṃ sulabhety arthaḥ ////
analyzed: hi yatas brahmaṇi avaiṣamya ādikam niścikyuḥ tasmāt prapañce tiṣṭhantaḥ api te brahmaṇi eva sthitāḥ muktiḥ teṣām sulabhā iti arthaḥ
translated: Since they have ascertained the absence of inequality etc. in Brahman, therefore, even while remaining in the world, they remain in Brahman. The meaning is that liberation is easy for them.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: BhG.

original: na prahṛṣyet priyaṃ prāpya nodvijet prāpya cāpriyam /
analyzed: na prahṛṣyet priyam prāpya na udvijet prāpya ca apriyam
translated: One should not rejoice on obtaining what is pleasant, nor grieve on obtaining what is unpleasant.

original: sthirabuddhir asaṃmūḍho brahmavid brahmaṇi sthitaḥ ////
analyzed: sthira buddhiḥ asaṃmūḍhaḥ brahma vid brahmaṇi sthitaḥ
translated: One of steady understanding, undeluded, knowing Brahman, abides in Brahman.

original: śrīdharaḥ / brahmaprāptasya lakṣaṇam āha na prahṛṣyed iti /
translated: Sridhar: The characteristic of one who has attained Brahman is stated thus: One should not rejoice.

original: brahmavid bhūtvā brahmaṇy eva yaḥ sthitaḥ sa priyaṃ prāpya na prahṛṣyet prakṛṣṭaharṣavān syāt /
analyzed: brahma vid bhūtvā brahmaṇi eva yaḥ sthitaḥ sa priyam prāpya na prahṛṣyet prakṛṣṭa harṣavān syāt
translated: One who, having become a knower of Brahman, abides in Brahman alone, should not rejoice on obtaining what is pleasant, should not become excessively delighted.

original: apriyam prāpya ca nodvijet na viṣīdatīty arthaḥ /
analyzed: apriyam prāpya ca na udvijet na viṣīdati iti arthaḥ
translated: And on obtaining what is unpleasant, one should not grieve, should not be dejected, is the meaning.

original: yataḥ sthirabuddhir sthirā niścalā buddhir yasya /
analyzed: yatas sthira buddhiḥ sthirā niścalā buddhiḥ yasya
translated: Because one has steady understanding, one whose understanding is steady, unmoving.

original: tat kutaḥ / yato 'saṃmūḍho nivṛttamohaḥ ////
analyzed: tat kutas yatas saṃmūḍhaḥ nivṛtta mohaḥ
translated: How is that? Because one is undeluded, free from delusion.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana:

original: yasmān nirdoṣaṃ samaṃ brahma tasmāt tadrūpam ātmānaṃ sākṣātkurvann āha na prahṛṣyed iti /
analyzed: yasmāt nirdoṣam samam brahma tasmāt tad rūpam ātmānam sākṣātkurvan āha na prahṛṣyet iti
translated: Since Brahman is free from faults and is equal, one who realizes the Self to be of that nature says thus: One should not rejoice.

original: duḥkheṣv anudvignamanāḥ sukheṣu vigataspṛhaḥ ity atra vyākhyātaṃ pūrvārdham /
analyzed: duḥkheṣu anudvigna manāḥ sukheṣu vigata spṛhaḥ iti atra vyākhyātam pūrva ardham
translated: The first half of this verse has been explained in the commentary on the verse, 'Undistressed in misery, and not longing for happiness' (3.30).

original: jīvanmuktānāṃ svābhāvikaṃ caritam eva mumukṣubhiḥ prayatnapūrvakam anuṣṭheyam iti vadituṃ liṅgapratyayau /
analyzed: jīvanmuktānām svābhāvikam caritam eva mumukṣubhiḥ prayatna pūrvakam anuṣṭheyam iti vaditum liṅga pratyayau
translated: The verbal affix and the nominal affix are used to state that the natural conduct of the liberated ones should be assiduously followed by the seekers of liberation.

original: advitīyātmadarśanaśīlasya vyatiriktapriyāpriyaprāptyayogyāc ca tannimittau harṣaviṣādāv ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: advitīya ātma darśana śīlasya vyatirikta priya apriya prāpti ayogyāt ca tad nimittau harṣa viṣādau iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that for one who is habituated to the realization of the non-dual Self, joy and sorrow, which are caused by the attainment of what is dear and what is not dear, are not possible.

original: advitīyātmadarśanam eva vivṛṇoti sthirabuddhiḥ sthirā niścalā saṃnyāsapūrvakavedāntavākyavicāraparipākeṇa
analyzed: advitīya ātma darśanam eva vivṛṇoti sthira buddhiḥ sthirā niścalā saṃnyāsa pūrvaka vedānta vākya vicāra paripākeṇa
translated: He explains the realization of the non-dual Self: 'Sthirabuddhiḥ', one whose intellect is firm, unmoving, free from doubt, due to the maturity of the investigation of the Vedanta statements preceded by renunciation.

original: sarvasaṃśayaśūnyatvena nirvicikitsā niścitā brahmaṇi buddhir yasya sa tathā labdhaśravaṇamananaphala iti yāvat /
analyzed: sarva saṃśaya śūnya tvena nirvicikitsā niścitā brahmaṇi buddhiḥ yasya sa tathā labdha śravaṇa manana phalaḥ iti yāvat
translated: One whose intellect is firmly fixed, free from doubt, in Brahman, is so called because he has attained the fruit of listening and reflection.

original: etādṛśasya sarvāsaṃbhāvanāśūnyatve 'pi viparītabhāvapratibandhāt sākṣātkāro nodetīti nididhyāsanam āha asaṃmūḍhaḥ /
analyzed: etādṛśasya sarva asaṃbhāvanā śūnya tve pi viparīta bhāva pratibandhāt sākṣātkāraḥ na udeti iti nididhyāsanam āha asaṃmūḍhaḥ
translated: Even though such a person is free from all disbelief, the realization does not arise due to the obstruction of contrary tendencies. Therefore, he says 'asammūḍhaḥ', 'undeluded', and speaks of meditation.

original: nididhyāsanasya vijātīyapratyayānantaritasajātīyapratyayapravāhasya paripākeṇa viparītabhāvanākhyasaṃmoharahitaḥ /
analyzed: nididhyāsanasya vijātīya pratyaya anantarita sajātīya pratyaya pravāhasya paripākeṇa viparīta bhāvanā ākhya saṃmoha rahitaḥ
translated: By the maturity of the stream of homogeneous cognitions uninterrupted by heterogeneous cognitions of meditation, he is free from delusion called inverted meditation.

original: tataḥ sarvapratibandhāpagamād brahmavid brahmasākṣātkāravān /
analyzed: tatas sarva pratibandha apagamāt brahma vid brahma sākṣātkāravān
translated: Then, due to the removal of all obstacles, the knower of Brahman, who has the direct experience of Brahman,

original: tataś ca samādhiparipākeṇa nirdoṣe same brahmaṇy eva sthito nānyatreti brahmaṇi sthito jīvanmuktaḥ sthitaprajña ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: tatas ca samādhi paripākeṇa nirdoṣe same brahmaṇi eva sthitaḥ na anyatra iti brahmaṇi sthitaḥ jīvanmuktaḥ sthita prajñaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: and then, due to the maturity of concentration, he abides only in Brahman, which is free from faults and even, and not elsewhere. Thus, the meaning is: one who abides in Brahman, the liberated while living, is one of steady wisdom.

original: etādṛśasya dvaitadarśanābhāvāt praharṣodvegau na bhavata ity ucitam eva /
analyzed: etādṛśasya dvaita darśana abhāvāt praharṣa udvegau na bhavataḥ iti ucitam eva
translated: For such a one, the absence of the view of duality is proper, so there is no joy or sorrow.

original: sādhakena tu dvaitadarśane vidyamāne
analyzed: sādhakena tu dvaita darśane vidyamāne
translated: But even when the view of duality exists for the aspirant,

original: 'pi viṣayadoṣadarśanādinā praharṣaviṣādau tyājyāv ity abhiprāyaḥ ////
analyzed: viṣaya doṣa darśana ādinā praharṣa viṣādau tyājyau iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: it is the intention that joy and sorrow should be abandoned by seeing the faults of objects, etc.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha.

original: evaṃ laukikapriyāpriyādiṣv api teṣāṃ sāmyam āha na prahṛṣyed iti /🔽na prahṛṣyet na prahṛṣyati /
analyzed: evam laukika priya apriya ādiṣu api teṣām sāmyam āha na prahṛṣyet iti  na prahṛṣyet na prahṛṣyati
translated: Thus, he says their equality even in worldly things like the beloved and the hated: He should not rejoice, etc.🔽He should not rejoice, he does not rejoice.

original: nodvijet nodvijate /
analyzed: na udvijet na udvijate
translated: He should not be distressed, he is not distressed.

original: sādhanadaśāyām evam abhyased iti vivakṣayā vā liṅ /
analyzed: sādhana daśāyām evam abhyaset iti vivakṣayā vā
translated: Or, the verbal ending is with the intention that one should practice thus even in the stage of means.

original: asaṃmūḍho harṣaśokādīnām abhimānanibandhanatvena saṃmohamātratvāt ////
analyzed: asaṃmūḍhaḥ harṣa śoka ādīnām abhimāna nibandhana tvena saṃmoha mātra tvāt
translated: He is not deluded, because joy, sorrow, etc. are mere delusions, being based on the notion of the self.

original: baladevaḥ / brahmaṇi sthitasya lakṣaṇam āha neti /
analyzed: baladevaḥ brahmaṇi sthitasya lakṣaṇam āha na iti
translated: Balarama. The characteristic of one who is established in Brahman is stated by na (not).

original: vartamāne dehe sthitaḥ prārabdhākṛṣṭaṃ priyam apriyaṃ ca prāpya na prahṛṣyen na codvijet /
analyzed: vartamāne dehe sthitaḥ prārabdha ākṛṣṭam priyam apriyam ca prāpya na prahṛṣyet na ca udvijet
translated: One who is established in the present body, on attaining what is pleasant and unpleasant drawn by past actions, should not rejoice nor be distressed.

original: kutaḥ / sthirā svātmani buddhir yasya saḥ /
analyzed: kutas sthirā sva ātmani buddhiḥ yasya saḥ
translated: Why? He whose intellect is firm in the self.

original: asaṃmūḍho 'nityena dehena nityam ātmānam ekīkṛtya mohaṃ na labdhaḥ /🔽brahmavit tādṛśaṃ brahmānubhavan /
analyzed: asaṃmūḍhaḥ nityena dehena nityam ātmānam ekīkṛtya moham na labdhaḥ  brahma vid tādṛśam brahma anubhavan
translated: He is not deluded, not having attained delusion by identifying the eternal self with the non-eternal body.🔽The knower of Brahman, experiencing such Brahman.

original: evaṃlakṣaṇo brahmaṇi sthito bodhyaḥ ////
analyzed: evaṃlakṣaṇaḥ brahmaṇi sthitaḥ bodhyaḥ
translated: One having such characteristics should be known as established in Brahman.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: BhG.

original: bāhyasparśeṣv asaktātmā vindaty ātmani yat sukham /
analyzed: bāhya sparśeṣu asakta ātmā vindati ātmani yat sukham
translated: One whose self is unattached to external contacts finds that happiness in the self.

original: sa brahmayogayuktātmā sukham akṣayam aśnute ////
analyzed: sa brahma yoga yukta ātmā sukham akṣayam aśnute
translated: He, whose self is united with Brahman, enjoys that imperishable happiness.

original: śrīdharaḥ / mohanivṛttyā buddhisthairye hetum āha bāhyasparśeṣv iti /
translated: Sridhar. The cause of firmness of intellect through the cessation of delusion is stated by bahir-sparshesv asakta-atma (one whose self is unattached to external contacts).

original: indriyaiḥ spṛśyanta iti sparśā viṣayāḥ /
analyzed: indriyaiḥ spṛśyante iti sparśāḥ viṣayāḥ
translated: Contacts are objects that are touched by the senses.

original: bāhyendriyaviṣayeṣv asaktātmānāsaktacittaḥ /
analyzed: bāhya indriya viṣayeṣu asakta ātmā anāsakta cittaḥ
translated: One whose mind is unattached to external sense objects.

original: ātmani antaḥkaraṇe yad upaśamātmakaṃ sāttvikaṃ sukham tad vindati labhate /
analyzed: ātmani antaḥkaraṇe yat upaśama ātmakam sāttvikam sukham tat vindati labhate
translated: He finds, obtains, that happiness which is of the nature of tranquillity and which is born of the quality of goodness in the internal organ, the mind.

original: sa copaśamaṃ sukhaṃ labdhvā brahmaṇi yogena samādhinā yuktas tadaikyaṃ prāpta ātmā yasya so 'kṣayaṃ sukham aśnute prāpnoti ////
analyzed: sa ca upaśamam sukham labdhvā brahmaṇi yogena samādhinā yuktaḥ tad aikyam prāptaḥ ātmā yasya saḥ kṣayam sukham aśnute prāpnoti
translated: And he, having obtained that happiness of tranquillity, being united with Brahman by yoga, by concentration, he whose self has attained oneness with that, enjoys, attains, imperishable happiness.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana.

original: nanu bāhyaviṣayaprīter anekajanmānubhūtatvenātipracalatvāt tadāsaktacittasya katham alaukike brahmaṇi dṛṣṭasarvasukharahite sthitiḥ 🔽syāt /
analyzed: nanu bāhya viṣaya prīteḥ aneka janma anubhūta tvena ati pracala tvāt tad āsakta cittasya katham alaukike brahmaṇi dṛṣṭa sarva sukha rahite sthitiḥ  / syāt
translated: But how can one whose mind is attached to external object-pleasure, which is very unsteady because experienced in many births, remain in Brahman, which is not of this world and is devoid of all seen happiness,

original: paramānandarūpatvād iti cet / na /
analyzed: paramānanda rūpa tvāt iti ced na
translated: if it is said that it is because Brahman is of the nature of supreme bliss? No.

original: tadānandasyānanubhūtacaratvena cittasthitihetutvābhāvāt /
translated: Because that bliss, not being experienced, cannot be the cause of the mind's abiding in it.

original: tad uktaṃ vārttike 🔽apy ānandaḥ śrutaḥ sākṣān mānenāviṣayīkṛtaḥ /
analyzed: tat uktam vārttike  api ānandaḥ śrutaḥ sākṣāt mānena a viṣayīkṛtaḥ
translated: This is said in the Varttika:🔽Even though bliss is directly heard, it is not made an object of cognition by the mind.

original: dṛṣṭānandābhilāṣaṃ sa na mandīkartum apy alam // iti /
analyzed: dṛṣṭa ānanda abhilāṣam sa na mandīkartum api alam iti
translated: It cannot even diminish the desire for seen bliss.

original: tatrāha bāhyeti /
analyzed: tatra āha bāhya iti
translated: There, he says: external, etc.

original: indriyaiḥ spṛśyanta iti sparśāḥ śabdādayaḥ /
analyzed: indriyaiḥ spṛśyante iti sparśāḥ śabda ādayaḥ
translated: The objects of sense are touched by the senses, hence they are contacts, such as sound, etc.

original: te ca bāhyā anātmadharmatvāt /
analyzed: te ca bāhyāḥ anātma dharma tvāt
translated: And they are external, because they are not the attributes of the self.

original: teṣv asaktātmānāsaktacittas tṛṣṇāśūnyatayā viraktaḥ sann ātmani antaḥkaraṇa eva bāhyaviṣayanirapekṣaṃ yad upaśamātmakaṃ sukhaṃ tad vindati
analyzed: teṣu asakta ātmā anāsakta cittaḥ tṛṣṇā śūnyatayā viraktaḥ san ātmani antaḥkaraṇe eva bāhya viṣaya nirapekṣam yat upaśama ātmakam sukham tat vindati  /
translated: Being detached from them, having a mind unattached to them, being free from craving, he finds that happiness which consists in tranquillity, which is independent of external objects, in the self, in the inner organ alone.

original: labhate nirmalasattvavṛttyā /
translated: He obtains it by the functioning of a pure mind.

original: tad uktaṃ bhārate
analyzed: tat uktam bhārate
translated: This is stated in the Bhagavad Gita:

original: yac ca kāmasukhaṃ loke yac ca divyaṃ mahat sukham /
analyzed: yat ca kāma sukham loke yat ca divyam mahat sukham
translated: The happiness that is in the world, and the great divine happiness,

original: tṛṣṇākṣayasukhasyaite nārhataḥ ṣoḍaśīṃ kalām // iti /
analyzed: tṛṣṇā kṣaya sukhasya ete na arhataḥ ṣoḍaśīm kalām iti
translated: are not worth a sixteenth part of the happiness of the cessation of craving.

original: athavā pratyagātmani tvaṃpadārthe yat sukhaṃ svarūpabhūtaṃ suṣuptāv anubhūyamānaṃ bāhyaviṣayāsaktipratibandhād alambhamānaṃ tad eva tadabhāvāl
analyzed: athavā pratyagātmani tvam padārthe yat sukham svarūpa bhūtam suṣuptau anubhūyamānam bāhya viṣaya āsakti pratibandhāt a lambhamānam tat eva tad abhāvāt
translated: Or else, the happiness which is the nature of the object denoted by the word you in the inner self, which is experienced in deep sleep, which is not obtained due to the obstruction of attachment to external objects, that very happiness he obtains

original: labhate /
analyzed: labhate
translated: because of the absence of that [attachment].

original: na kevalaṃ tvaṃpadārthasukham eva labhate kintu tatpadārthaikyānubhavena pūrṇasukham
analyzed: na kevalam tvam padārtha sukham eva labhate kintu tad padārtha aikya anubhavena pūrṇa sukham
translated: Not only does he obtain the happiness of the object denoted by the word you, but he also obtains the complete happiness by the experience of identity with that object.

original: apīty āha sa tṛṣṇāśūnyo brahmaṇi paramātmani yogaḥ samādhis tena yuktas tasmin vyāpṛta
analyzed: api iti āha sa tṛṣṇā śūnyaḥ brahmaṇi paramātmani yogaḥ samādhiḥ tena yuktaḥ tasmin vyāpṛta
translated: This is what is said: He, being free from craving, is united with yoga, with meditation, on Brahman, the supreme Self. He is engaged in that.

original: ātmāntaḥkaraṇaṃ yasya sa brahmayogayuktātmā /
analyzed: ātmā antaḥkaraṇam yasya sa brahma yoga yukta ātmā
translated: He whose inner organ, the self, is thus united with Brahman, is one whose self is united with Brahman-yoga.

original: athavā brahmaṇi tatpadārthe yogena vākyārthānubhavarūpeṇa samādhinā yukta aikyaṃ prāpta ātmā tvaṃpadārthasvarūpaṃ yasya sa tathā /
analyzed: athavā brahmaṇi tad padārthe yogena vākya artha anubhava rūpeṇa samādhinā yuktaḥ aikyam prāptaḥ ātmā tvaṃ padārtha svarūpam yasya sa tathā
translated: Or, he is so called because his Self has become united with Brahman, the object of the word 'tat', through concentration, which is the experience of the meaning of the sentence through the connection with Brahman.

original: sukham akṣayam anantaṃ svasvarūpabhūtam aśnute vyāpnoti sukhānubhavarūpa eva sarvadā bhavatīty arthaḥ /
analyzed: sukham akṣayam anantam sva svarūpa bhūtam aśnute vyāpnoti sukha anubhava rūpaḥ eva sarvadā bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: Or, he who is yuktah, endowed; samadhin, with concentration, with the experience of the meaning of the sentence in the form of the identification of the meaning of the word 'that' with the meaning of the word 'I'; atah, therefore; asnute, enjoys; sukham, the imperishable, endless, and intrinsic bliss; eva, alone; sarvadah, at all times. The meaning is: he becomes one with the experience of bliss.

original: nitye 'pi vastuny avidyānivṛttyabhiprāyeṇa dhātvarthayoga aupacārikaḥ /
analyzed: nitye pi vastuni avidyā nivṛtti abhiprāyeṇa dhātvartha yogaḥ aupacārikaḥ
translated: Even in regard to a permanent entity, the application of the meaning of the verbal root (asnu) is figurative, with the intention of the cessation of ignorance.

original: tasmād ātmany akṣayasukhānubhavārthī san bāhyaviṣayaprīteḥ kṣaṇikāyā mahānarakānubandhinyāḥ
analyzed: tasmāt ātmani akṣaya sukha anubhava arthī san bāhya viṣaya prīteḥ kṣaṇikāyāḥ mahā naraka anubandhinyāḥ
translated: Therefore, being desirous of the experience of imperishable bliss in the Self, one should turn away the senses from external objects, from the attachment to worldly pleasures which is momentary and which leads to great hell.

original: sakāśād indriyāṇi nivartayet tāvataiva ca brahmaṇi sthitir bhavatīty abhiprāyaḥ // //
analyzed: sakāśāt indriyāṇi nivartayet tāvatā eva ca brahmaṇi sthitiḥ bhavati iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: The idea is that by that alone there is abiding in Brahman.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha:

original: sa ca bāhyasparśeṣu viṣayasukheṣv asaktātmā anāsaktamanāḥ /
analyzed: sa ca bāhya sparśeṣu viṣaya sukheṣu asakta ātmā anāsakta manāḥ
translated: And he is asaktatma, whose mind is unattached; bahihsrpesu, to external objects, to worldly pleasures.

original: tatra hetur ātmani jīvātmani paramātmānaṃ vindati sati prāpte yat sukhaṃ tad akṣayaṃ sukham /
analyzed: tatra hetuḥ ātmani jīvātmani paramātmānam vindati sati prāpte yat sukham tat akṣayam sukham
translated: The reason is: yat sukham, the bliss; yad asaktam, which is unattached; atmani, in the Self, in the individual Self; vidati, one finds; sati, when there is; paramatmani, the Supreme Self; tam, that; sukham, bliss; asnute, one enjoys.

original: sa evāśnute prāpnoti /
analyzed: saḥ eva aśnute prāpnoti
translated: He alone attains it.

original: na hi nirantaram amṛtāsvādine mṛttikā rocata iti bhāvaḥ ////
analyzed: na hi nirantaram amṛta āsvādine mṛttikā rocate iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that, indeed, to one who is constantly tasting nectar, clay does not appeal.

original: baladevaḥ / paurvauttaryeṇa svaparātmānāv anubhavatīty āha bāhyeti /
translated: Balarama. To explain that one experiences one's own and others' selves in sequence, he says unattached to external objects etc.

original: bāhyasparśeṣu śabdādiviṣayānubhaveṣu asaktātmā san yadātmani svasvarūpe 'nubhūyamāne sukham tadādau vindati /
analyzed: bāhya sparśeṣu śabda ādi viṣaya anubhaveṣu asakta ātmā san yadā ātmani sva svarūpe nubhūyamāne sukham tadā ādau vindati
translated: Being unattached to external objects, i.e., to the experiences of sound etc., when one experiences bliss in one's own nature, i.e., in one's own form that is being experienced, one obtains that in the beginning.

original: tad uttaraṃ brahmaṇi paramātmani yogaḥ samādhis tadyuktātmā san yad akṣayaṃ mahadanubhavalakṣaṇaṃ sukham tad aśnute labhate ////
analyzed: tat uttaram brahmaṇi paramātmani yogaḥ samādhiḥ tad yukta ātmā san yat akṣayam mahat anubhava lakṣaṇam sukham tat aśnute labhate
translated: After that, being one whose self is endowed with yoga, i.e., concentration, on Brahman, the Supreme Self, one enjoys that imperishable great bliss, which is characterized by experience, one obtains it.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: BhG 5.22

original: ye hi saṃsparśajā bhogā duḥkhayonaya eva te /
analyzed: ye hi saṃsparśa jāḥ bhogāḥ duḥkha yonayaḥ eva te
translated: For, O son of Kunti, those enjoyments that arise from contact are verily the sources of sorrow.

original: ādyantavantaḥ kaunteya na teṣu ramate budhaḥ ////
analyzed: ādi antavantaḥ kaunteya na teṣu ramate budhaḥ
translated: They have a beginning and an end; the wise man does not delight in them.

original: śrīdharaḥ / nanu priyaviṣayabhogānām api nivṛtteḥ kathaṃ mokṣaḥ puruṣārthaḥ syāt /
translated: Sridhar. Now, if even the enjoyments of beloved objects are to be renounced, how can liberation be the human goal?

original: tatrāha ye hīti /
analyzed: tatra āha ye hi iti
translated: To that he says for etc.

original: saṃsparśā viṣayās tebhyo jātā ye bhogāḥ sukhāni /
analyzed: saṃsparśāḥ viṣayāḥ tebhyaḥ jātāḥ ye bhogāḥ sukhāni
translated: Those enjoyments, those pleasures that arise from contacts, i.e., from objects,

original: te hi vartamānakāle 'pi spardhāsūyādivyāptatvād duḥkhasyaiva yonayaḥ kāraṇabhūtāḥ /
analyzed: te hi vartamāna kāle pi spardhā asūyā ādi vyāpta tvāt duḥkhasya eva yonayaḥ kāraṇa bhūtāḥ
translated: are verily the sources of sorrow, are the causes of sorrow, because they are pervaded by rivalry, envy etc., even in the present moment.

original: tathādimanto 'ntavantaś ca /
analyzed: tathā ādimantaḥ ntavantaḥ ca
translated: And they have a beginning and an end.

original: ato vivekī teṣu na ramate ////
analyzed: atas vivekī teṣu na ramate
translated: Therefore, the discerning one does not delight in them.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /🔽nanu bāhyaviṣayaprītinivṛttāv ātmany akṣayasukhānubhavas tasmiṃś ca sati tatprasādād
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ  nanu bāhya viṣaya prīti nivṛttau ātmani akṣaya sukha anubhavaḥ tasmin ca sati tad prasādāt
translated: Madhusudana.

original: eva bāhyaviṣayaprītinivṛttir itītaretarāśrayavaśān naikam api sidhyed ity āśaṅkya
analyzed: eva bāhya viṣaya prīti nivṛttiḥ iti itaretara āśraya vaśāt nā ekam api sidhyet iti āśaṅkya
translated: Now, if the attachment to external objects ceases, there is the experience of imperishable bliss in the self, and if that exists, the cessation of attachment to external objects is due to the grace of that. Thus, due to the mutual dependence, neither would be established. Anticipating this,

original: viṣayadoṣadarśanābhyāsenaiva tatprītinivṛttir bhavatīti parihāram āha ye hīti /
analyzed: viṣaya doṣa darśana abhyāsena eva tad prīti nivṛttiḥ bhavati iti parihāram āha ye hi iti
translated: he says that the cessation of attachment to external objects is only through the practice of seeing their faults.

original: hi yasmād ye saṃsparśajā viṣayendriyasambandhajā bhogāḥ kṣudrasukhalavānubhavā iha vā paratra vā rāgadveṣādivyāptatvena duḥkhayonaya 🔽eva te /
analyzed: hi yasmāt ye saṃsparśa jāḥ viṣaya indriya sambandha jāḥ bhogāḥ kṣudra sukha lava anubhavāḥ iha vā paratra vā rāga dveṣa ādi vyāpta tvena duḥkha yonayaḥ  eva te
translated: For, indeed, those enjoyments born from contact, born from the connection of the senses with objects, which are the experience of small pleasures here or in the next world, are indeed the sources of sorrow due to being pervaded by attachment, aversion, etc.

original: te sarve 'pi brahmalokaparyantaṃ duḥkhahetava eva /
analyzed: te sarve brahma loka paryantam duḥkha hetavaḥ eva
translated: All of them, up to the world of Brahman, are indeed causes of sorrow.

original: tad uktaṃ viṣṇupurāṇe
analyzed: tat uktam viṣṇupurāṇe
translated: This is stated in the Vishnu Purana:

original: yāvataḥ kurute jantuḥ saṃbandhān manasaḥ priyān /
analyzed: yāvataḥ kurute jantuḥ saṃbandhān manasaḥ priyān
translated: As many attachments to the mind the creature makes,

original: tāvanto 'sya nisvanyante hṛdaye śokaśaṅkavaḥ // iti /
analyzed: tāvantaḥ sya nisvanyante hṛdaye śoka śaṅkavaḥ iti
translated: so many arrows of sorrow pierce his heart.

original: etādṛśā a na sthirāḥ kintu ādyantavantaḥ /
analyzed: etādṛśāḥ na sthirāḥ kintu ādi antavantaḥ
translated: Such are they, and not stable, but have a beginning and an end.

original: ādir viṣayendriyasaṃyogo 'ntaś ca tadviyoga evaṃ tau vidyete yeṣāṃ te pūrvāparayor asattvān madhye svapnavad āvirbhūtāḥ kṣaṇikā mithyābhūtāḥ
analyzed: ādiḥ viṣaya indriya saṃyogaḥ ntaḥ ca tad viyogaḥ evam tau vidyete yeṣām te pūrva aparayoḥ asattvāt madhye svapna vat āvirbhūtāḥ kṣaṇikāḥ mithyābhūtāḥ
translated: The beginning is the conjunction of the sense objects and senses, and the end is their separation. Those who have these [dualities] in the middle, like in a dream, are momentarily manifest and falsely existent due to the non-existence of the beginning and end.

original: tad uktaṃ gauḍapādācāryaiḥ ādāv ante ca yat tv asti vartamāne 'pi tat tathā iti /
analyzed: tat uktam gauḍapāda ācāryaiḥ ādau ante ca yat tu asti vartamāne tat tathā iti
translated: This has been stated by the teacher Gauḍapāda: What exists in the beginning and end, that exists in the present as well.

original: yasmād evaṃ tasmāt teṣu budho vivekī na ramate pratikūlavedanīyatvāc ca prītim anubhavati /
analyzed: yasmāt evam tasmāt teṣu budhaḥ vivekī na ramate pratikūla vedanīya tvāt ca prītim anubhavati
translated: Since it is so, therefore the wise one, the discerning one, does not delight in them, and due to their being disagreeable to experience, he does not experience pleasure.

original: tad uktaṃ bhagavatā patañjalinā pariṇāmatāpasaṃskāraduḥkhair guṇavṛttivirodhāc ca duḥkham eva sarvaṃ vivekinaḥ YogS / iti /
analyzed: tat uktam bhagavatā patañjalinā pariṇāma tāpa saṃskāra duḥkhaiḥ guṇa vṛtti virodhāt ca duḥkham eva sarvam vivekinaḥ iti
translated: This has been stated by the Blessed Lord Patañjali: For the discerning one, everything is indeed suffering due to the sufferings of transformation, grief, and impression, and due to the contradiction of the functions of the gunas. (Yoga Sutra 2.15)

original: sarvam api viṣayasukhaṃ dṛṣṭam ānuśravikaṃ ca duḥkham eva pratikūlavedanīyatvāt /
analyzed: sarvam api viṣaya sukham dṛṣṭam ānuśravikam ca duḥkham eva pratikūla vedanīya tvāt
translated: All the experienced worldly pleasures and the pleasures obtained from the scriptures are indeed suffering, because they are disagreeable to experience.

original: vivekinaḥ parijñātakleśādisvarūpasya na tv avivekinaḥ /
analyzed: vivekinaḥ parijñāta kleśa ādi svarūpasya na tu avivekinaḥ
translated: For the discerning one who has fully understood the nature of afflictions etc., not for the nondiscerning one.

original: akṣipātrakalpo hi vidvān atyalpaduḥkhaleśenāpy udvijate yathorṇatantur atisukumāro
analyzed: akṣi pātra kalpaḥ hi vidvān ati alpa duḥkha leśena api udvijate yathā ūrṇa tantuḥ ati su kumāraḥ
translated: For the wise one is like a bowl of scales, he is distressed even by the slightest bit of suffering, just like a very delicate thread.

original: 'py akṣipātre nyastaḥ sparśena duḥkhayati netareṣv aṅgeṣu tadvad vivekina eva madhuviṣasaṃpṛktānnabhojanavat
analyzed: pi akṣi pātre nyastaḥ sparśena duḥkhayati na itareṣu aṅgeṣu tadvat vivekinaḥ eva madhu viṣa saṃpṛkta anna bhojana vat
translated: just as a drop of poison placed in a cup of sugar does not cause pain by contact with the other ingredients, but only when it enters the body, so also for the wise, like eating food mixed with honey and poison.

original: sarvam api bhogasādhanaṃ kālatraye 'pi kleśānubiddhatvād duḥkhaṃ na mūḍhasya bahuvidhaduḥkhasahiṣṇor ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: sarvam api bhoga sādhanam kāla traye pi kleśa anubiddha tvāt duḥkham na mūḍhasya bahuvidha duḥkha sahiṣṇoḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Just as a drop of poison placed in a cup of honey causes pain by contact, but not the other parts of the body, so for the discerning person, all means of enjoyment are painful, like eating food mixed with honey and poison, because they are pierced by afflictions at all three times, not for the deluded one who endures many kinds of suffering.

original: tatra pariṇāmatāpasaṃskāraduḥkhair iti bhūtavartamānabhaviṣytkāle
analyzed: tatra pariṇāma tāpa saṃskāra duḥkhaiḥ iti bhūta vartamāna bhaviṣyat kāle
translated: There, by the sufferings of change, pain, and formation, at the past, present, and future times,

original: 'pi duḥkhānubiddhatvād aupādhikaṃ duḥkhatvaṃ viṣayasukhasyoktaṃ /
analyzed: duḥkha anubiddha tvāt aupādhikam duḥkha tvam viṣaya sukhasya uktam
translated: the object-pleasure is said to have a superimposed nature of suffering because it is pierced by suffering.

original: guṇavṛttivirodhāc cety anena svarūpato 'pi duḥkhatvam /
analyzed: guṇa vṛtti virodhāt ca iti anena duḥkha tvam
translated: And by the contradiction of the modes of the qualities, its nature is also suffering.

original: tatra pariṇāmaś ca tāpaś ca saṃskāraś ca ta eva duḥkhāni tair ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: tatra pariṇāmaḥ ca tāpaḥ ca saṃskāraḥ ca te eva duḥkhāni taiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: There, change, pain, and formation are themselves sufferings. By them, is the meaning.

original: itthaṃbhūtalakṣaṇe tṛtīyā /
analyzed: itthaṃbhūta lakṣaṇe tṛtīyā
translated: The instrumental case is in the sense of such a thing.

original: tathā hi rāgānubiddha eva sarvo 'pi sukhānubhavaḥ /
analyzed: tathā hi rāga anubiddhaḥ eva sarvaḥ pi sukha anubhavaḥ
translated: For it is thus: all experience of pleasure is indeed pierced by attachment.

original: na hi tatra na rajyati tena sukhī ceti sambhavati /
analyzed: na hi tatra na rajyati tena sukhī ca iti sambhavati
translated: For it is not possible that one is not attached there, and yet is happy by that.

original: rāga eva ca pūrvam udbhūtaḥ san viṣayaprāptyā sukharūpeṇa pariṇamate /
analyzed: rāgaḥ eva ca pūrvam udbhūtaḥ san viṣaya prāptyā sukha rūpeṇa pariṇamate
translated: And attachment itself, having arisen before, changes into the form of pleasure by the attainment of the object.

original: tasya ca pratikṣaṇaṃ vardhamānatvena svaviṣayāprāptinibandhanaduḥkhasyāparihāryatvād duḥkharūpataiva /
analyzed: tasya ca pratikṣaṇam vardhamāna tvena sva viṣaya aprāpti nibandhana duḥkhasya aparihārya tvāt duḥkha rūpa tā eva
translated: And because it is inevitable that there will be suffering caused by the non-attainment of its object, since it increases moment by moment, it is indeed suffering in nature.

original: yā hi bhogeṣv indriyāṇām upaśāntiḥ paritṛptatvāt tat sukham /
analyzed: yā hi bhogeṣu indriyāṇām upaśāntiḥ paritṛpta tvāt tat sukham
translated: For that satisfaction of the senses in enjoyments due to satiety is happiness.

original: yā laulyād anupaśāntis tad duḥkham /
analyzed: yā laulyāt anupaśāntiḥ tat duḥkham
